pros: Opportunity to establish professional relationships with professors and learn from them. Meet and help a wide variety of students, and also learn through them.

pros: Generally, the people are nice and the office environment is positive. Staff are allowed 1 floating paid personal day per month. HR does fun health initiatives with prizes. Supervisors are fairly flexible with time off requests. Staff and Faculty councils exist to discuss issues with your peers to present to the executive cabinet. Medical insurance includes decent coverage.
cons:
When I was hired, I accepted an offer lower than the amount I was currently making with HR’s assurance that I would be up for my first raise in 6 months. I worked hard, went above and beyond, and asked for the raise at 6 months only to be told that merit raises aren’t offered at all. They will ask and expect you to do more than your job description with no chance of a reward for doing it.
They used to have a great 401k contribution/match and decreased it severely - I’m not sure if it’s even happening with COVID anymore.
HR, with the exception of a few very kind individuals, seem annoyed when you ask them for help and bounce you around between their staff when you ask questions.
Full-time employees are expected to be reachable during all waking weekday hours, as well as some occasional weekends.
Accruing vacation time is a very slow process and you are only given 10 days of sick time at the beginning of calendar year. While you are allowed to take your sick time to take care of sick family, less than 1 day/month is nowhere near the amount needed. They are also not flexible with working mothers.
There are other things that could be listed but these are the main points of concern.

review_title: Student Technician at ArtCenter Educational Media Equipment Center
pros:
The main benefits are a decent hourly salary (you may get a small raise after you've been in the ranks), exposure and elevated access to select equipment (while you're in term and working -- applicable mostly to photo majors). Hours are quite flexible, as you can work just a few days a week, or work Mon.-Sat. You can get a first hands on experience working with industry equipment, and you get paid. The atmosphere is pretty chill, and crew/coworkers are helpful. Plus, you'll get to meet and interact with many of the other school staff and faculty. It is to your best interest to ask questions when you can, and don't be afraid to ask for help as well. Don't pretend to know everything.

Also, the PIN is mightier than the sword.
cons: You will be dealing with some unsavory characters at the counter sometimes... A few are rude, self-entitled, and incredibly impatient. You must learn to be professional and cordial, and when necessary, leave such hairy interactions to full time staff or management. There are times where there are no one around and it's dead quiet, and also times where the counter is being bombarded with people wanting things 'right now' -- sometimes when there's only one worker available (hint: that might be you)!!!

job_title: Concept Artist in Los Angeles, CA
pros: very cool place to study
cons: a little too expensive tho

pros: Amazing students and faculty. The place is brimming with creativity drawing some of the best talent from around the world.
cons: The institution is a bureaucratic relic, reveling in its former glory days as one of the only art and design schools of its kind. Those days are gone and as the world and their competition marches forward, they sluggishly lurch forward. The management's philosophy hails from 30 years ago and before when autocratic management ruled the day. The rhyme or reason for many of the decisions make no sense and take no account of the end user and/or impact on staff morale. Students have an advocate and so do the faculty but the staff advocate, will immediately escalate your issue to the head of HR and that is because the staff are an after thought. Which wouldn't be a problem except the relationship between staff and HR tends to be a punitive one. Mediocrity is encouraged and rewarded.

review_title: I'm Still Here and I Agree With Those Who Have Left!
job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Pasadena, CA
pros: Brilliant faculty and students!  That is why the culture is still worth it.
cons: Petty, selfish, power seeking administration.  Many department chairs are corrupt, self-serving, vindictive and ineffective.  Transportation is a joke.  FIlm is a joke.  The reputation of the school is plummeting. The senior management is the worst!! They are totally self absorbed, mean spirited, hypocritical, often vicious to one another and their faculty and staff.   The new team is just as bad as the old one!  Loren may be worse because he does it with the veneer of caring, when he clearly could care less about the faculty, staff and students.  Its all about him and his superficial super crafted messaging.  I do not mean the marketing team which spends time trying to know students, faculty and staff and alumni. They're great. In fact, so is the alumni service team.

job_title: Creativist & Transportation Student Representative in Pasadena, CA
pros: Throughout the college you will see powerful female roles in many departments. Every one is exquisite to work for. Celeste G. And Liz L. Will fight tooth and nail for anyone of there subordinates. The will always support and lift up those around them with utmost care and respect. I applaud them and look forward to how the progress the college.
cons: Overall It's system is flawed in such a way, that it's on progression is slowed to a sloth pace. It requires students to make initial moves and an endless abyss of emails to get anything done. Students may not see change for them at all over the 4 years minimum 8 years maximum of attendance. The college tends to step on its own toes.... Often.....

review_title: At one time, I was both teacher and department Chair.

pros: It is the best school in the world for the study of Communications, Photography, Environmental and Transportation Design.
cons: The students. They are of the highest caliber and of the truest dedication to their career. It is indeed a challenge to help them get on with their career.

review_title: An Interesting Grind, for a Time
job_title: Assistant Director of Admissions in Pasadena, CA
pros: Interesting students, adequate travel, numerous unlisted educational benefits such as free extension courses and access to the campus library.
cons: No upward momentum. Assembly line structure to keep salaries low. Innovation and creative thinking is not welcomed. Tangled bureaucracy makes decisions based on what is best for the school, not the students, and has no interest in adapting and changing with the times. Advancement is based on loyalty, not merit of ideas. Criticism is often indirect or confusing, leading to a culture of dishonesty and an inability to grow. Good position for a recent college graduate, bad for someone interested in the field or for career and salary growth.

pros: Creative environment is amazing. Lots of talented folks sharing their craft and their knowledge of the craft. With so many long time employees around you would think that it must be a great place to work. Beautiful campus. Exciting expansion plans.
cons: Just because they stick around doesn't mean they love the job. You hear the buzz around the place and many are pissed off but just can't move on. Expansion can mean growing pains.

review_title: Great environment, filled with cutting edge technology, art, excitement, creativity

cons: The pay is poor, and it is nearly impossible to get a kind word or recognition from the administration.  Raises are unheard of, and there is no real tenure track,  and the salaries are low.
